metadata.case_name: Workmen of Dimakuchi Tea Estate represented by Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha v. Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate

facts.text: Dr. K. P. Banerjee appointed as assistant medical officer of Dimakuchi Tea Estate with effect from November 1, 1950, subject to satisfactory medical report and on probation for three months.

Appointment letter stated that during probation suitability for permanent employment would be considered; if unsuitable, seven days' notice terminating appointment; if guilty of misconduct, instant dismissal; if suitable at end of probation, confirmed in service.
In February 1951, Dr. Banerjee given increment of Rs. 5 per mensem.
On April 21, 1951, Dr. Banerjee received letter from manager Mr. Booth terminating services with effect from April 22, 1951, with one month's salary in lieu of notice. No reasons given initially.

Manager's reply to Dr. Banerjee's query: reasons on medical side outside manager's jurisdiction, best known to Dr. Cox; main reason deceitful addition of figures to medical indent after signed by Dr. Cox.

Manager's letter to union: discharged on ground of incompetence in medical duties; Dr. Cox found incompetent, insufficient knowledge of microscopical and laboratory work; faulty quinine injection to Mr. Peacock causing severe illness nearly paralysis.
Cause espoused by Mangaldai Circle of Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha.
Conciliation proceedings held unsuccessfully over termination.

Referred to Tripartite Appellate Board consisting of Labour Commissioner Assam, representatives of Indian Tea Association and Assam Chah Karmachari Sangha; Board recommended reinstatement from date of discharge.
Management offered 28 months' salary and allowances in lieu of reinstatement; appellants did not agree.
Dr. Banerjee received Rs. 306-1-0 on May 22, 1951 and left the tea garden.

Government of Assam notification dated December 23, 1953 referring dispute to Shri U.K. Gohain, Additional District and Sessions Judge under s.10(1)(c) IDA: Whether management justified in dismissing Dr. K.P. Banerjee A.M.O.? If not, entitled to reinstatement or other relief?
Tribunal held Dr. Banerjee not a workman, no industrial dispute, no jurisdiction.
Appeal to Labour Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta affirmed: dispute must be between employers and workmen.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on March 14, 1956, limited to whether dispute re non-workman falls within s.2(k) IDA.
Parties proceeded on footing that Dr. Banerjee was not a workman within the Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether a dispute in relation to a person who is not a workman falls within the scope of the definition of 'industrial dispute' contained in s.2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Expression 'of any person' in third part of s.2(k) is of wide import, not to be equated with 'any workman'; dispute between employer and workmen connected with non-employment of Dr. Banerjee (not a workman) is industrial dispute.

Limitations on 'any person': real/substantial dispute where relief possible; relates to same establishment; person is employee discharged/in service/candidate; workmen have nexus via personal interest or general labour welfare.
Dispute satisfies limitations: employer can give relief; same establishment; discharged employee; workmen interested as Dr. Banerjee in union, dismissal without charge/opportunity affects all.

respondent_arguments.text: Dr. Banerjee not workman; no industrial dispute as must be between employers/workmen; 'any person' limited to workmen class including discharged/future workmen.
'Any person' read in context/scheme of Act; cannot include supervisory staff like Dr. Banerjee; no community of interest with workmen.

court_reasoning.text: S.2(k) analysed in three parts: dispute/difference; between employers/employers, employers/workmen, workmen/workmen; connected with employment/non-employment/terms/conditions of labour of any person.
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Any person' not unlimited; must read in context of Act's scheme/objects promoting employer-workmen relations.

court_reasoning.text: Act for workmen (manual/clerical); distinguishes from supervisory; objects: amity, settlement of disputes between specified parties, prevent strikes/lockouts, lay-off relief, collective bargaining.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions like s.18, s.33, s.36 limit to employers/workmen.

court_reasoning.text: Literal wide reading leads to absurdities e.g. dispute over District Magistrate's employment; no community of interest.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words understood to harmonise with subject/object (Maxwell).

court_reasoning.text: True limitations: real dispute capable of settlement/adjudication; parties directly/substantially interested; relates to same establishment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Any person = person in whose emp/non-emp etc. workmen as class have direct/substantial interest/community of interest.

court_reasoning.text: Dr. Banerjee medical/technical staff, not workman; workmen no direct/substantial interest in his non-employment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if union member, no community of interest test satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. (partial dissent?): Words 'any person' plain/ordinary meaning includes non-workmen; no contextual restriction to workman class; difficulties in respondent's limitations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Text cuts off, but supports wide interpretation.

holdings.text: Expression 'any person' in s.2(k) IDA subject to limitations: real dispute; parties have direct/substantial interest/community of interest in person's emp/non-emp/terms/conditions.
Dispute re Dr. Banerjee's termination not industrial dispute as no community of interest with workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narendra Kumar Sen v. All India Industrial Disputes Labour Appellate Tribunal
precedents_cited.relevance: Absurd results of wide 'any person'; crucial test: direct/substantial interest.

precedents_cited.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal, Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: 'Any person' includes discharged workmen; non-employment within definition.

precedents_cited.case_name: C.P. Transport Services Ltd. v. Raghunath
precedents_cited.relevance: Individual dispute of workman as industrial dispute.

precedents_cited.case_name: Newspapers Ltd. v. State Industrial Tribunal, U.P.

precedents_cited.relevance: Wide 'any person' but concerned discharged workmen.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dalhousie Jute Co. Ltd. v. S.N. Modak
East India Industries Madras Ltd. v. Their Workmen

precedents_cited.relevance: Majority: includes non-workmen; minority: limited to employer/workmen class.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of industrial dispute/workman; authorities/procedure; binding nature of awards; strikes/lockouts; during pendency restrictions.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed holding that the dispute regarding termination of Dr. K.P. Banerjee, who was not a workman, did not constitute an industrial dispute under s.2(k) IDA due to lack of community of interest with the workmen.

key_quotes.text: 'Any person' in s.2(k) means a person in whose employment or non-employment or terms of employment, or conditions of labour the workmen as a class have a direct or substantial interest - with whom they have, under the scheme of the Act, a community of interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding defining scope of 'industrial dispute'.

key_quotes.text: The crucial test is one community of interest and the person regarding whom the dispute is raised must be one in whose employment, non-employment, terms of employment or conditions of labour the parties to the dispute have a direct or substantial interest.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for determining if non-workman dispute is industrial.

key_quotes.text: A dispute between the employers and employees to be an industrial dispute within the meaning of section 2(k) of the Industrial Disputes Act, must be between the employers and the workmen.
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Labour Appellate Tribunal's view affirmed by majority.
